segments.text: And now from the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN, the AX files with your
host, David Axelrod.
Fred Hotberg has a great story and there are a lot of chapters to it as an entrepreneur,
as head of the Small Business Administration, as chairman of the Exporti Import Bank, as
a Democratic activist and as one of the country's leading advocates for gay and lesbian
rights.
Fred Hotberg is currently a fellow at the Institute of Politics and we sat down to talk about
his life and career and the issues on which he's played such a big role.
Fred Hotberg, it's great to see you.
I want to thank you on the front end, as I will on the back, for being a fellow at the
Institute of Politics, this fall.
You've been a great asset to us here and to these students and good to see you here.
The great benefit of doing this podcast is I learned about people who I thought I knew
and the thing, I vaguely knew the story of your family.
It's really an impressive story and your mom's story is an impressive story.
Tell me about your family.
Well, my mom was born in Leipzig in Germany in 1927 and she had an older brother named
Zigfried whom I named.
I thank my parents every day, they did not name me Zigfried but just Fred.
It's not Fred, because it's not Alvigos, it's just Fred.
In 1933, my mother's brother was a few years older, she was like nine.
Kind of got roughed up by some Nazi Hitler youth and pushed down a flight of stairs and
I think that was the last straw for my grandfather and he said we have to get out.
They moved to Holland.
They probably wouldn't have survived.
They probably wouldn't have survived.
What's remarkable is one third of the German Jews left Germany.
If you think about it, if you're living in the community and one out of three franges
leaving, this is not like a, you should be asking the question, what did they know that
I don't know?
So it was a sizable portion got out in advance.
They went to Holland, they went to Amsterdam and they figured that bought them time and
they looked at, they went to a trip to Palestine.
My grandfather came to Havana and actually it was when President Obama opened up in Cuba
that reminded my mother, she says, you know your grandfather went to Havana, I remember
that now and she had forgotten.
And then New York and then decided on New York.
I could have been a Cuban American for all I know, it was almost.
Yeah.
That was later in the day.
It was 1937.
So actually my grandfather was already in America and my grandmother went to get her visa
extended and the consular officer were not extending visas but you still have a week,
you should get on a boat because if you get on the boat they'll let you get off the boat
and they got on a boat.
They packed up within a few days or a week.
My mother, her brother and my grandmother and some furniture and sale to America.
Yeah.
What I was going to say was as you pointed out it got harder and harder and people were
turned away.
Obviously St. Louis is a historic and tragic story of Jews being turned away and sent back
to Europe.
My grandfather clearly was a smart man that he had the foresight and he had some enough
cash to get out.
So tell me about your mom because she was really a pioneer in business.
You know, so she got here in 1937, went to Hunter High School, went to NYU and she got
married at the age of 22.
So in those days she got quote unquote her MRS, she got married, she never finished
college and she always said, well I wanted to have a little extra money.
My dad had a dry goods store and she wanted a little extra cash.
So her father manufactured pocketbooks, belts, wallets, small leather goods and my mom would
actually go to the better stores in New York and she had a good eye and she would buy
them and the crash word is knock them off.
The polite word is I said they tastefully reinterpreted them for them.
And she so they would.
Is that on advice of counsel?
Yes, they tastefully reinterpreted them.
So she'd go to Lord and tailor and places like that.
And so he made these leather goods and she was sort of the designer and then she got the
idea of selling them in 17 magazine and she put an ad in the magazine, took 2000s and
1000s of their wedding money, which was a lot of money in 1951 and bet it all.
And that ad was probably the best ad the company ever ran in 60 years.
You still have that ad?
You still have a copy of the 17 magazine that have the ad and that launched the business.
Because the Lillian Vernon line became a catalog and quite a business.
So it actually started as it was called Vernon Specialties and then it turns out, not surprisingly
David, there was a plumbing supply company with the same name in Mount Vernon.
So it became Lillian Vernon Specialties and that was like a mouthful.
So they just dropped the specialties and became Lillian Vernon.
And how did the business grow?
So it started with just ads and ladies home journal, red book, cause you know, teen magazines,
like things like that.
And then in the very late 50s came out.
So they would have the ads and people would mail in there.
And in those days they mailed in cash and my job was to take those singles and put them
in packs of 50, take the quarters, nickels and dimes, and roll them and you know roll
them.
And I would go to the bank of my mom and we didn't have an ad in machine and I would sit
on the bank to manage his desk and I would actually add up the checks.
So we had a deposit slip and how many people said it's like it's a wonderful life.
It's a wonderful life.
So it was, it was, you know, it had very simple beginnings, you know, and I don't think had
the great ambition that developed over time.
And my mom and dad got divorced in 70, 69.
So I think she then sort of more fully devoted herself to the business.
And then I joined it.
And I joined the business in 75.
Was it always your intent to do that?
Was that your?
Pretty much so.
Your ambition?
And just as an early day, in those days, color printing was really expensive.
So we would take one page in the catalog would be all the copy and the color would be only
photographs on the following page because that way you had waste color by having copy
on it.
Right.
So, you know, but that was a different era of printing and production of anything else.
Now she says that you're joining the business was a kind of a watershed event in terms of
growing the business.
What did you do with that business that turned it into started off as a successful business.
But I think when you, I read somewhere when you came, it was a $5 million business that
ran into a $200 million a year business.
She had the creative spark.
She had, you know, her book is called The Knife and Winter.
She had a great eye for spotting products and trends early on.
One of the keys in the business was we did a lot of things monogram.
We put your name on anything and anything and everything you can imagine.
So I think when I came, I came out of business school and I was the only person with a college
degree at the company.
And we, you know, I felt it was like a high school student who had never exercised.
This was, the raw material was there, but we hadn't really analyzed the data.
We didn't really expand it out.
I think when I got there, took her from 51 to 75 to get to $5 million, I think we thought,
well, God, if we double the business to $10 million, that'll be a lot.
And I applied, and this is a lot of things.
You had gotten an MBA at Columbia.
So, yeah.
So I applied, you know, some marketing, polling, market research, some financial models, stuff
I learned in business school.
And we were able to figure out what we actually did in a minute is we would calculate sales
per square inch in the catalog, the way a store calculates still per square foot.
And we started products that sold a lot.
We put more of those in, sold the didn't per square inch.
We put less in and we started really managing the enterprise.
And I got there in 75 by 86.
We were well over $100 million.
It is Forbes described as one of the great success stories of American entrepreneurship.
You went public in 1987.
First time a company founded by a woman went public.
So that's quite a legacy.
It was very heady.
She really wanted, I think she wanted that acknowledgement.
I remember once you J.A. wanted to honor her as like, you know, leading business woman,
she goes, no, I can be a business person.
I'm not going to be the woman business person.
I acknowledge we've-
She's ahead of her time.
She was way ahead of her time.
Yeah.
I mean, we had more.
We had so many women executives.
They said there's not enough men in this company.
Now you, but you guys had some sort of falling out, right?
You over succession.
Yes.
Like she didn't want to leave the business.
She didn't want to leave the business.
What happened was I turned the, it was partly the tyranny of the calendar.
I turned 40, the year she turned 65.
And I had a lot of people saying, okay, you know, you're present.
You're going to, when are you going to really run this place, going to be the CEO and take
over?
So I'm getting, I'm like revving and people are saying to her, you're going to retire
you're 65 now.
She's like digging.
She's revving in the other direction.
I almost think there are times I wonder if our birthdays did not coincide in the same
year.
Maybe that we would have been a little more relaxed about it.
But it, yeah, it came to a head.
I turned 40 and 92 and I left a year later.
And was that-
Was it a painful thing?
Oh, we didn't talk for about a year, year and a half.
That's tough.
That was, I mean-
Not exactly an advertisement for going into business with your family.
It's a challenge to go into.
Family businesses are a challenge.
I've talked to other people about it.
I mean, it, because one day in the same, in the same 20 minutes, you're a business partner,
you're going to subordinate and it's your mother.
Or father.
And that's a lot of different roles to try and keep meshing together.
Yeah.
Maybe we could have found somebody who would have been a, there are a number of consultants
now who do this kind of work, work with family businesses.
Somehow we didn't deploy that.
But I don't, you know-
Let me say, and I think I can, I have leave to say it, the dynamics of a Jewish family
has its own complications.
Has its own complications.
And, you know, to be honest with you, being open the gay, I'm sure, added another whole
dimension to that.
Yeah.
Well, let me ask you about that.
Talk to me about, you, you, you came of age in a generation, we're in an entirely different
time now and good that we are.
But how, how was it for you as a kid in claiming your own identity?
It was very tricky then.
I sort of, I came out, I called it sort of the PSPA post-Stonewall pre-AIDS in the 70s.
And, you need to start, Barney Frank has sort of come out retail.
First, you start coming out to yourself and, and figure out what's going on here.
And I actually, as it became more clear to me, I actually decided to go to therapy and
I, I was on the couch for 20 plus years.
Just try and just come to terms with it, which would be very different today.
Yeah.
It was a much more hostile environment.
When you say come to, yeah, come to terms with it, tell me about that.
Well, I mean, I remember first I got to the therapist and I never forget I get there.
After the first session, he says, maybe you want to lie down on the couch.
I was that anxious.
And you know, it took me within six months, I'm talking about being homosexual, not gay,
I really said, so should we like do shock treatment?
I mean, what do we do?
You know, I, because you thought that was somehow, that was, yeah.
So it was, it was a very, you know, it was, it was a very inhospitable time.
And did you, and did you talk to your parents about this?
Not for, no, I didn't talk to my, so when I came out to my mother, I had a, I met somebody
and we were living together.
And in those days, it was pre-cell phone.
He had his own phone and I had to be at two phones in the apartment.
Just to keep up of a fiction for those who you want to.
Right.
So, so I remember she co-found somehow got his name, calls the phone.
No, doesn't say anything.
He picks up, hangs up.
One minute later, my phone rings.
Hi, sweetheart.
Are you home?
Are you home alone?
Anybody, really?
So I ultimately came out to her because I said, all right, I'm living with a guy and I,
this is, so in those days I started the conversation saying that I was bisexual.
I figured that was a way of easing into the subject.
Which I wasn't.
I mean, I had sex with him, but I, I figured that was-
Plus, that'll make it easier for her.
A little easier for her to come accommodate to it.
But she had a really rough time.
She had a rough time.
I mean, she talked about, she was going to exile herself to Europe and move back to Europe.
Really?
Yeah.
I'm going to move to Switzerland.
I don't think I can tell with this.
That's, that's painful.
Yeah, it was pretty intense.
And we were working together.
Yeah.
It had a lot of drama in it, in that regard.
You know, and you can tell suppliers of what a company, people in the company say, or people
to business with.
So it took a lot of, I'm very fortunate I found a good therapist and worked through a lot
of that stuff.
Yeah.
You feel it would be much different today.
Oh, it's totally different.
My generation, everybody of my generation has a coming out story.
You know, there's some passage that you've come out to your family, to your friends.
Today, a lot of kids don't come out.
They're just, they're out.
It's not something they have to, it's not a migration.
So and it's also, and it's younger.
And there's acceptance.
Yeah.
Much more acceptance.
Much more every day.
Yeah, I've met a number of students here who are fellows who talked about it.
And I remember when I was at the Small Business Administration jumping ahead, you know, I'd
have parents come and talk to me because it's all right, my boss is gay.
Maybe you can help me.
How do I talk to my son or daughter?
So yeah, I mean, we as a country made enormous strides.
You know, I had a conversation like this with Barney Frank last year and he described
his own very difficult journey and how painful it was to have to kind of hide who he was
and how lonely it was for him.
It was very poignant.
You know, as he described going to fundraisers and people would come as couples and he'd
go home alone.
So now did you-
And finally Barney did come up with the concept of don't ask, don't tell, because that was
Barney's life.
I know it's that a lot of that policy that happened to him because Barney was influential.
This is also partly, you know, that's how Barney navigated the world.
Yeah.
You were part of the Clinton administration.
What was your thought when the don't ask, don't tell policy about the military was developed?
Well, I actually was the finance chair of something called the Campaign for Military
Service, which was sort of a coalition of different civil rights organizations that
was working to build support for what we thought President Clinton wanted to do in terms of
integrating the military.
So I left Lillian Vernon and literally within 10 days I moved myself to Washington and I
worked here for Washington for six months as the finance chair working in finance and
strategy with Tom Stoddard and a number of other people on that.
And we thought-
And that was Clinton's intention to integrate gays into the military.
Totally.
Ran into a political buzz saw and then kind of retreated to the don't ask him.
Sam Anand was no help.
Yeah.
Who was chairman of the armed service committee.
And he got passed over for Secretary of Defense so whether he had his own personal peak with
the president about it, but he certainly made it difficult.
And what was your reaction when that became the policy?
Well, it was enormous disappointment.
I mean, we all, you know, we raised something like $10 million, which was a lot of money
in the 90s to try and raise for-
I remember when that used to be a lot of money in politics.
Yes, exactly.
That was a lot of money those days.
And so it was, I remember listening to the speech, and Bill Clinton was genius at this,
you know, we're listening.
And as we're listening to that, I think he's going in our direction.
You know, he was so smart at honoring both sides.
Yes, salamonic.
Totally.
So we're sitting there and then at the end we say, all right, we got the rhetoric, they
got the policy.
It took another 17 years and President Obama did it, but it took 17 more years to get there.
Yeah, I was in the room when, and you were too, I'm sure, when the president, President
Obama signed the policy of repealing that.
That was one of the most moving days.
I have a choice.
That was one of the most moving days.
And you know what's the most moving thing about it?
Was the ovation that Admiral Mullen God, who was chair of the Joint Chiefs of Staff,
who started off not necessarily that comfortable with the change in policy and ended up being
one of its great champions.
I remember the initial meetings in the administration when the president said, I'm not, Mullen,
Secretary of Defense Gates.
There were some others there.
General Cartwright, who was the vice chair of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the president
said, I didn't ask you here to discuss this.
I asked you here to tell you that I want to change this policy.
We're going to change this policy, but I want to do it in a way that's not disruptive,
and I want your cooperation.
And it was really a process.
And as you know, he came under a lot of fire from the community for not doing it fast enough,
but he wanted to do it legislatively.
And that was the right way to go.
Totally.
I mean, we're seeing now the problem with executive orders.
They have kind of a short life.
Right.
Right.
So, tell me, you started off reluctantly, and then you really became an activist in the
community.
So that was quite a transition.
Yeah, the way I understand that David is, I think, I don't want to be a victim.
And one thing about building your own sense of self and self as a self esteem is to actively
do something about it.
So I think I got involved in the late 70s on LGBT issues.
I think it was just called gay issues then.
Yes, yeah.
With Lambda Legal Defense and others.
To me, I think it was a healing process.
I think a way of healing that pain is to do something about it and to work on it.
And that actually made it, I was actively fixing something versus just feeling bad.
And so it was as much a personal journey as it was a political journey.
We're going to take a short break and we'll be right back with Fred Hotberg.
Very scary people.
The podcast is back.
I'm Donnie Wahlberg.
And in season two, we're diving into the story of Paul Bernardo and Carla Humulka.
It seemed like they were the perfect couple, the Ken and Barbie Dream marriage.
We expect our monsters to look like monsters and they don't always find out how the couple
next door became the killers known as Ken and Barbie.
Listen to very scary people, the Ken and Barbie killers wherever you get your podcasts.
As you point out, we've made tremendous progress in this country on this issue.
Obviously the marriage issue was a huge, huge, huge step forward.
But we still have these issues still linger with us.
President Trump has now rolled back the rights of transgender Americans to serve.
This is now a matter of legal contention.
So these battles still go on.
The battles still go on and the progress is fragile.
It's very fragile.
And I think the transgender issue has just been harder.
In many ways, there's some aspects of it are better and easier because some of the best
advocates on transgender issue are mothers and fathers who have children who are trans.
I saw one of the Human Rights Campaign Dinner just last weekend.
It was so moving.
It was a nine-year-old son.
But for many parts of society, we're very binary and so it's confusing to people.
There's a story I never will forget with Ted Kennedy.
I was with Ted Kennedy in 2004 during the Kerry campaign and he was doing a press conference
on hate crimes and he asked me to comment so I came and at the end of it he leans over
and says, Fred, I don't know what to do with these trisectuals.
I just don't know.
I said, Senator, they're transgender.
They're not trisectual.
And here was one of the greatest advocates for LGBT issues the Senate had ever seen.
And he was trying to, one, I think emotionally square it and also politically, because I
remember him saying, I got all these senators to agree on gay and lesbian.
I have to now go back and get them all to rethink and add another dimension to be
cosponsors of an employment bill.
So, you know, he, and now granted that, it's over a decade ago.
But so I think that it's been harder.
And society's made, I think, made remarkable progress on the transgender issue in very
short time.
I mean, that comment with Ted Kennedy was 13, 14 years ago.
You know, one mark of the progress that we've made generally on these issues is the fact
that your appointment to run the SBA was a matter of some controversy back in the 90s
in the Clinton administration.
Talk about that.
Well, so I worked on President Clinton's first campaign, worked on his, and then worked
again in 1996.
And it was the day after election day, and he had a receiving line at the building museum
in Washington and said, you know, he's getting well-wishers.
And I remember I walked up to him and shook his head, and I said, congratulations.
And I knew him at that point having worked on 92 and things in between.
I don't think I rehearsed it.
I simply said, Mr. President, I want to come work for you.
And he turned around.
He said, well, call Nancy Hernreich tomorrow.
So she came to your business car, and I go, would you do what the President says, call
someone in the morning?
Call them in the morning.
Yes.
So there were a couple of jobs open, and ultimately the SBA seemed like the right place.
Well, it makes you, you, you were a star entrepreneur and a small businessman.
Right.
Actually, I really understood those, the people we were serving.
But that nomination ran into a buzz saw.
It took over seven months.
It was been part held up.
I got direct confirmation of it being gay.
You know, it was like, oh, well, clearly this is one more quota filling, incompetent,
unqualified person that President Clinton is sending to the Senate, and we're going
to just stole them.
Yeah.
There were other appointments.
Yes.
Robert Achtenberg had a challenging time.
Jim Hormel had to get a recess appointment.
It was very different than, you know, when President Obama came through, and that was
not an issue in the confirmations.
Yeah.
So that's really a measure of the progress we made.
Talk to me about your tenure at the SBA.
You know, up until working for President Obama, that was the greatest job I ever had.
It was a great job.
I was there for the second half of the Clinton administration.
I'm always proud of the fact we almost quadrupled loans to women and minorities, and at the
time we didn't even double them in total.
So we did it, and we speeded up service times.
We automated many parts of the agency.
And I really got to learn about a lot of businesses.
And most importantly, I learned how to work in government.
Yeah.
I always thank President Clinton for having given, having the confidence that gave me
my first job in government, because, you know, it's very different than the private
sector, than the public sector, and some people have a reference to president.
President's learning that, right?
Yes, he's learning that, Leon.
Well, talk to me about small businesses in our economy and what the challenges are.
I mean, there is a concern about small business creation today, and the pace at which businesses
are being created.
Some, you know, if there were Republican here, they would say, well, this is the result
of burdensome regulation.
But what do you say about all of this?
Well, we are in a period where small business formation is at a low point.
It's not clear.
You know, it's hard to determine exactly why.
How much of that has to do with, you know, access to capital, which is what the SBA really
provides, access to capital price, a guarantee to induce a bank to make a loan.
So there is that.
There are a lot of, there are a lot of sort of, whether it be a person having a two person
or one person computer tech company that does, you know, programs, you know, laptop at home.
So there are a lot of those kind of businesses.
A lot of them are one person businesses.
We're also in the gig economy where that may also be overshadowing some of the aspects
of it.
Does it worry you?
Oh, sure it worries me because a lot of innovation comes from small businesses.
And we still in our head have that as part of the American dream that you're going to
start a business and build a business and give it to your kids.
Right.
You know, one of the things that strikes me is that we see a lot of consolidation going
on in businesses, in business.
The internet has created an opportunity for large scale enterprises to overwhelm smaller
business.
It's also given an opportunity, you know, we dealt with a number of small food companies,
you know, at Exim Bank that there's a barbecue sauce company or a small winery that actually
can go online, have a web presence, ship anywhere in the world and either access if
they need to, SBA or XM financing if needed.
So in many ways that's true, but it's also opened it up and made that much more possible.
So there's an alternative that just say, well, I have this great barbecue sauce.
I've got to find supermarkets to sell.
I can sell direct.
Yeah.
The other side of the equation is the Amazon phenomenon where you can order almost anything
from Amazon and the small retailers are facing enormous pressure.
You know, I mean, walking around Hyde Park, you just see this still more and more empty
storefronts because it's hard and harder to make that work.
Yes.
I wonder whether there's going to be some pushback against all of this consolidation.
I mean, you can't stop technology and there is a certain ease to sitting at your kitchen
table and ordering stuff and having it show up at your doorstep.
On the other hand, you know, it's tough on communities.
It's tough on communities.
It's tough on the tax base of communities because, you know, I mean, what we're going
to be seeing with a number of shopping malls that are going to be vacant because once
they start to, you know, once a certain percentage become vacant, then everybody wants to walk
into a mall where a third of the stores are empty.
And what's going to happen to that?
What's how we're going to repurpose that real estate and what that's going to do with the
tax base for a lot of communities that rely on real estate taxes?
I don't think we've figured all that out yet.
You took a break in between your public service at the New School, the Milano School of International
Affairs Management and Urban Policy doing somewhat the same sort of things we're doing
here at the Institute of Politics.
But you came back to public service under the Obama administration.
As head of what is, it turns out, a pretty controversial agency, the Export-Import Bank.
I think a lot of people don't know what the Export-Import Bank is.
So, uh...
Sure.
So, well, one reason I took a pause at the Milano was we had a Republican in the White
House.
I would have much preferred to worked in Washington, but that wasn't an option.
So, your students benefited from your hiatus.
I met with a Harris student saying, talks about it a little bit.
So what the Export-Import Bank does very briefly was actually started by FDR.
And interestingly, the very first transaction ever done was actually selling currency to
Cuba.
The Exem Bank took US American silver and minted into coins in Philadelphia.
We sold them their first currency, or maybe not on first one of the early currencies.
So what the Exem Bank does, it exists for one purpose only, supporting US jobs.
So, if you're a small business, there's a company here, Darlie, that makes fire trucks.
They have to some of them here in Illinois and the rest, I think, is in Wisconsin.
Yeah, in Wisconsin.
So, they sell fire trucks to places like Lagos in Nigeria to China.
And they have to compete with German companies, Dutch companies, and Chinese companies.
And each of those competitors come with financing when they're selling their firefighting equipment
in those countries.
In other words, excuse me, financing for the people who are buying their equipment.
Exactly.
You know, it's a little bit like here at the University of Chicago.
I mean, no one applies to college.
And after they get in and said, oh, now how am I going to pay $300,000 for the next four
years?
You have to think about it in advance.
So if a community or a country's buying firefighting equipment or a jet airplane or whatever, the
financing is integral to the sales proposition.
So we would provide, for a fee, a guaranteed loan so that JP Morgan Chase, Citibank, HSBC,
any bank, any U.S. bank, would make a loan to the municipality of Lagos.
We would guarantee it for a fee.
And with that fee, that was enough to give comfort to financial institution to make the
loan because there are concerns about credit worthiness, but frankly, with a full faith
in credit backing of the U.S. government, the bank will make the loan and the buyers
don't like the default on the U.S. government.
I always say it's not a good idea.
It's a fault on Uncle Sam.
But so basically you're providing financing for people overseas and that has come under
attack for a variety of reasons.
And so the other thing we would do, and a company with it is Charlie also, sometimes
needs working capital so they can buy the equipment and so forth.
And sometimes local, their local bank may not be comfortable because they say, well,
all of our sales are overseas and they go, well, what if you don't get paid?
So we will provide a guarantee to the bank to make a working capital loan so they can
buy the inventory and do that.
90% of the customers at the Exynbank are small businesses.
So sometimes people think, oh, Exyn is the bank of Boeing and bank of big companies,
but let's remember that it's not 90% of the dollars, but it is 90% of the transactions
are small companies.
Yeah, but the buzzsaw that you ran into is that the Koch brothers and some others of
a libertarian bent viewed the Exynbank as intruding on the market.
In other words, greasing deals that wouldn't otherwise happen.
